> Might that be one reason why it works so poorly? If you think of a
P-NEAT=

> substrate for a checkers board evaluation, maybe it would be better
to t=
ake
> contiguous regions instead of ordering based on age.
> 
> It would be=
 an interesting area for someone to conduct research.
> 
> Thanks again for=
 clarifying these issues.
>

Hey Jeff,

The problem with trying to use P-NE=
AT on checkers is tied to the
direct encoding of genes.  If P-NEAT was to r=
un on the 4100-connection
substrate that HyperNEAT encodes, it would not be=
 possible to defeat
the simplech heuristic within 20 generations as HyperNE=
AT does.  I do
not believe that anything besides an extraordinary amount of=
 luck
would allow the weights to behave in concert to form even something a=
s
simple as a piece counter (which actually, by itself, is not complex
enou=
gh to defeat the heuristic).

Ignoring the evolution speed difference betwe=
en HyperNEAT and P-NEAT,
the other problem is generalization.  Because P-NE=
AT is a direct
encoding, it can only learn weights that it has needed for a=
 single
game of checkers in a single generation.  Even with a deterministic=

opponent, mutating a few links in the substrate causes radical changes
in =
the following generation's evaluation because picking a different
move once=
 causes simplech to pick a different move and this in turn
causes a snowbal=
l effect that results in a completely different game.
With a direct encodin=
g, all of the link weights have a chance of being
mutated, even ones that h=
ad no bearing on fitness.  This means that as
the games keep changing their=
 focus on different configurations,
P-NEAT is potentially destroying valid =
connections in mutation.

I believe that these problems would affect any di=
rect encoding.  IMHO,
anything besides using another technique to reduce th=
e input space
(i.e. NEAT-EI) cannot compete on the same level as an indirec=
t
encoding for highly geometric tasks.  Even if adding crossover could
give=
 NEAT-EI or P-NEAT an order of magnitude faster convergence on a
solution f=
or defeating simplech, it would still not learn as fast as
HyperNEAT and st=
ill faces the problem of generalization against the
non-deterministic heuri=
stic.
